title: Erdős Problem #282: Greedy Algorithm for Egyptian Fractions
description: Does the greedy Egyptian fraction algorithm terminate when x has odd denominator and A = odd integers? Fibonacci (1202): yes for A = ℕ. Erdős–Graham conjecture squares fail. Status: OPEN.

references: Fibonacci (1202): greedy terminates for A = ℕ

sections.title: Core Definitions
sections.summary: Define Egyptian fraction representation, representability, greedy step, and greedy termination.

sections.title: Fibonacci's Theorem
sections.summary: The greedy algorithm terminates for all rationals in (0,1] when A = ℕ \ {0}.

sections.title: The Odd Denominator Question
sections.summary: Stein's question: does greedy terminate for odd-denominator rationals with A = odd integers?

sections.title: Graham's Representability
sections.summary: Graham (1964): algebraic conditions for representability with denominators in congruence classes.

sections.title: Square Denominators and General Framework
sections.summary: Erdős–Graham conjecture that greedy fails for squares. Greedy termination implies representability.

overview.historicalContext: Egyptian fraction decomposition dates to ancient Egypt and was systematized by Fibonacci in 1202, who proved the greedy algorithm terminates for A = ℕ. Erdős and Graham (1980) posed variants for restricted denominator sets. Stein asked about odd denominators. Graham (1964) gave algebraic conditions for representability in congruence classes, but greedy termination is harder.
overview.problemStatement: Does the greedy Egyptian fraction algorithm terminate when the starting rational has odd denominator and the allowed denominators are odd positive integers?
overview.proofStrategy: We formalize Egyptian fraction representations, the greedy algorithm step, and termination. We state Fibonacci's classical result, Stein's odd-denominator question, Graham's representability theorems, and the Erdős–Graham conjecture about square denominators.
keyInsights: Fibonacci (1202): greedy always terminates for A = ℕ — the classical result
Stein's question: restricting to odd denominators and odd-denominator rationals
Graham (1964): algebraic conditions determine representability in congruence classes
Greedy termination is strictly harder than representability
Erdős–Graham conjecture that greedy fails for square denominators 'almost always'

conclusion.summary: Erdős Problem #282 asks whether the greedy Egyptian fraction algorithm terminates for odd-denominator rationals using only odd denominators. While Fibonacci's classical theorem covers A = ℕ and Graham characterized representability in congruence classes, greedy termination for restricted sets remains poorly understood.
conclusion.implications: A positive answer would extend the classical Fibonacci result to the most natural restricted setting. A negative answer would reveal fundamental limitations of the greedy approach for Egyptian fractions.
openQuestions: Does the greedy algorithm terminate for all odd-denominator rationals using odd denominators?
For which infinite sets A does the greedy algorithm always terminate?
Does the greedy algorithm fail for square denominators for almost all rationals?
Can non-greedy strategies always find representations where greedy fails?
